section.title: Introduction
section.para: Maintaining an exact and synchronized time in an operating system is important. For example, planning and calendaring applications rely on it to track time correctly and notify users about appointments on time. For clustered applications, individual host machines often require synchronized system time for mutual communication.

section.title: Implementation
section.para: The built-in hardware clock is not a reliable time source and manual correction of the system time may cause malfunction of critical applications. That is why the Network Time Protocol (NTP) is designed to synchronize the system time over the network. Its goal is to maintain the absolute time, and use it to synchronize the system time of all machines within a network.

Since &sls; 15, &chrony; is the default implementation of NTP. &chrony; includes two parts; &chronyd; is a daemon that can be started at boot time and &chronyc; is a command line interface program to monitor the performance of &chronyd;, and to change various operating parameters at runtime.

section.title: How it works
section.para: Depending on its configuration, &chronyd; can maintain the exact time on a single machine, or additionally act as a time server for other machines within a network.

section.title: Maintaining the exact system time on a machine
section.para: This case is very common on desktop computers where you only need to keep the system time exact. The NTP service continuously queries and adjusts the system time with reliable time servers in the network.

section.title: Providing the exact time to multiple machines
section.para: If you need to maintain the exact system time on multiple machines within a network, we recommend configuring at least one of the machines as a local time server. The local time server will maintain the exact time from a reliable (external) time server and provide the time information at the same time so that other machines can synchronize with it.

This approach is better than letting all the machines within a network synchronize their system time with an external time server. It saves the network bandwidth and allows for more secure setup where time server clients do not have access to the external network.
